intro: Siphocampylus retrorsus var. eximius, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, golden-yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland or shaded areas. Its leaves are lanceolate and have a slightly hairy texture, while its stems are upright and often branched. The variety eximius is distinguished by its more showy flowers and slightly different leaf morphology compared to the typical form.
